I have never written "Functional tests" using JUnit. I have however written
JUnit tests that drive a Swing GUI. In fact I have written a number of
classes to assist me in doing this.

There are three problems I discovered attempting to test a Swing GUI:

1) Getting hold of a handle onto the components that your code has displayed
to the user
2) Interacting with the components once you have a handle
3) Inspecting the results of your interactions without breaking the
single-threaded nature of Swing/AWT

Taking these individually:

1) I started off by solving this using reflection, i.e. the class I was
testing would hold a reference to a Frame (for example). Typically this
would be held as a private instance variable. I would then use reflection to
get hold of that reference. Unfortunately this approach fell down where I
had for various reasons not stored a handle to my component. For example
when showing a dialog box. This sort of thing is typically transient, and
you don't always need to hold a permanent reference to it.

The solution I came up with was to effectively write a "global listener". To
listen out for "window open" events. When a window open event occurred I
would record the handle for the window that was opened. This was implemented
using a custom EventQueue.

Once you have a handle on the window you can then "search" it for any
sub-components that you want. I wrote some helper code that would enable me
to perform searches like "given this window, find me the button with the
text "OK" on it".


2) Once you have a handle you then want to do stuff with it. E.g., click the
"OK" button. Type in some text in a text box. etc. This is relatively easily
implemented by submitting dummy events to that handle. E.g. to click a
button, send an event to enter that component, send an event to signal mouse
down, send an event to signal mouse up, send an event to leave the
component. The AWT/Swing event handling does the rest to raise higher level
events (e.g. action events) etc

3) The single threaded nature of AWT/Swing, means that once a window is
shown to the user it is effectively "owned" by the AWTThread. Your test
cases must execute within this thread - otherwise (as I discovered!) you get
spurious exceptions thrown. In addition you want to do write test sequences
like "click this button, wait until the dialog shows, click this other
button, wait for the dialog to disappear, fill in some text, wait
again...etc". In other words your test needs to be executing within the AWT
Thread, but it needs to hand back control every now and then for it to
handle the events that you have been raising.

I implemented this by extending TestCase - I called it JFCTestCase. This
handles all the threading issues, and provides a helper method to
temporarily suspend the test, and allow the AWT Thread to continue with
other stuff.

It has been my intention to send this code to the group once I had tidied
things up a bit. If anyone once to see an "advance" copy I can supply one
(not currently on a machine where I can get to it though)


Hope that is of some interest

Matt

Subject: [junit] Functional Testing with JUnit


Has anyone tried to drive Functional Tests with JUnit?  How did you 
accomplish it?  In particular, how could you drive a Swing GUI?

By "Functional Tests", I mean tests that check the entire application 
as a black-box (or very near to black-box testing).  It would launch 
the appliction, drive the GUI, and interpret the output of the system.

My team has been very sucessful with Unit Testing, and we want to 
advance to running Functional Tests.

- Greg
